revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=March 2014}} {{Year in Belgium|2013}} Events in the year '''2013 in [[Belgium]]'.
==Incumbents== *[[List of Belgian monarchs|Monarch]]: [[Albert II of Belgium|Albert II]] (abdicated 21 July), [[Philippe of Belgium|Philippe]] (ascended 21 July) *[[Prime Minister of Belgium|Prime Minister]]: [[Elio di Rupo]]
==Events== *January 1: [[Bart De Wever]] ([[New Flemish Alliance]]) becomes mayor of [[Antwerp]]. *January 13: Following accusations of tax evasion, Belgium's Dowager [[Queen Fabiola of Belgium]] has her annual allowance cut by over 400,000 pounds. *February 9: Five people killed in a plane crash at [[Brussels South Charleroi Airport|Charleroi airport]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-21393907 |title=Belgium plane crash closes Charleroi airport |work=BBC News |date=February 9, 2013}}</ref> The airport was closed shortly after the crash.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2013/0209/366921-belgium-plane-crash/ |title=Five people killed in plane crash at Charleroi Airport in Belgium |work=RTÉ News |date=February 9, 2013}}</ref> *February 21: 30,000 angry workers take to the streets of [[Brussels]] to demonstrate against government austerity plans.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.euronews.com/nocomment/2013/02/22/demonstration-in-brussels/ |title=Demonstration in Brussels |work=Euronews |date=February 21, 2013 |access-date=2014-06-05 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140606225955/http://www.euronews.com/nocomment/2013/02/22/demonstration-in-brussels/ |archive-date=2014-06-06 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> *May 4: During a railway accident in [[Wetteren]] several tank cars filled with [[acrylonitrile]] explode. *May 19: [[R.S.C. Anderlecht|Anderlecht]] draw against [[S.V. Zulte Waregem|Zulte Waregem]] to win the [[Belgian Pro League|Jupiler Pro League]]. *May 21: [[Soccer]] club [[Beerschot AC]] declared bankrupt by the Court of Commerce. *May 30: [[Pope Francis]] accepts the resignation of [[Aloys Jousten]] as [[bishop of Liège]] *July 3: King [[Albert II of Belgium]] announces his abdication in favour of his son [[Philippe, King of the Belgians|Philippe]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-23167525|title=Belgium's King Albert II announces abdication |publisher=BBC News |date=3 July 2013|access-date=11 June 2017}}</ref> *July 14: [[Jean-Pierre Delville]] consecrated as bishop of Liège *July 21: King [[Albert II of Belgium]] abdicates in favour of his son King [[Philippe, King of the Belgians|Philippe]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/belgiums-new-king-albert-ii-abdicates-after-20year-reign-to-make-way-for-son-philippe-8724400.html |title=Belgium's new King: Albert II abdicates after 20-year reign to make way for son Philippe |work=The Independent |date=July 21, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dw.de/belgiums-albert-ii-abdicates-to-make-way-for-philippe/a-16964753 |title=Belgium's Albert II abdicates to make way for Philippe |work=Deutsche Welle |date=July 21, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/07/21/world/europe/belgium-new-king/index.html |title=Belgium's King Albert II gives up throne to son |work=CNN |date=July 21, 2013}}</ref> *July 25: First official heatwave in Belgium since the [[2006 European heat wave]]. *August 25: [[Sebastian Vettel]] wins the [[2013 Belgian Grand Prix]]. *October 6: [[Samson Kiptoo Bunge]] wins the Marathon of [[Brussels]] in 2:15.49. *October 8: [[François Englert]] and Briton [[Peter Higgs]] awarded the Nobel prize for Physics. *October 12: Popgroup [[Clouseau]] make a comeback with the song "Vliegtuig" {Airplane} in the Ultratop 50. *October 19: Ten parachutists and a pilot die in a plane crash shortly after take-off.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.sky.com/story/1156862/ten-parachutists-killed-in-belgium-plane-crash |title=Ten Parachutists Killed In Belgium Plane Crash |work=Sky News |date=October 19, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2467472/Belgium-plane-crash-kills-10-parachutists.html |title=At least 10 parachutists killed when their plane crash lands in a field in Belgium minutes after take-off |work=Daily Mail |date=October 19, 2013}}</ref> *December 3: Three heavy pile-ups occur on the [[A19 road (Belgium)|A19 motorway]] due to fog *December 7: [[Veerle Baetens]] wins the [[European Film Award]] for Best Actress. ''[[Death of a Shadow]]'' wins in the category Best Short Film.
==Sports== *February 27: [[Ellen van Dijk]] wins [[2013 Le Samyn des Dames]] *August 23-26: [[Ellen van Dijk]] wins [[2013 Lotto-Belisol Belgium Tour]]
==Deaths== *October 9: [[Wilfried Martens]], 77, 60th and 62nd [[Prime Minister of Belgium]].
==See also== *[[2013 in Belgian television]]
==References== {{reflist}} {{Years in Belgium}} {{Year in Europe|2013}}
[[Category:2013 in Belgium| ]] [[Category:2013 in Europe|Belgium]] [[Category:2010s in Belgium]] [[Category:Years of the 21st century in Belgium]] [[Category:2013 by country|Belgium]]
{{belgium-stub}}

{{Infobox company | name = CFAO Ghana | logo = CFAO Ghana logo.jpg | logo_size = | type = [[Limited company|Public]] | traded_as = | genre = [[Automotive industry]] | foundation = 1909 | founder = | location_city = Airport bypass Airport Bypass Road BP 70 Accra, Ghana, [[Accra]], [[Greater Accra Region|Greater Accra]], [[Ghana]] | location_country = Ghana | location = | locations = Accra, Kumasi, Takoradi, Tema | area_served = | key_people = Paulo Fernandes
[[Managing Director]] | industry = | products = [[Trade|trading]] - [[office equipment]], [[Automobile|automotive]], household appliance, industrial | services = Servicing - Car Dealership - Equipment | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.cfaomotors-ghana.com/?id_rub1=32&id_rub2=80&id_rub3=119&col=32&col2=80 www.cfaomotors-ghana.com] | footnotes = }} [[File:CFAO Stand.jpg|thumb|262x262px]] '''CFAO Ghana''', also known as '''CFAO Motors Ghana''', is a [[Ghana]]ian [[automobile]]s company.[http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/snapshot/snapshot.asp?ticker=CFAO:GN Cfao Ghana Ltd (CFAO:Accra)]. investing.businessweek.com.[https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/CFAO:GN/profile Cfao Ghana Ltd]. ''bloomberg.com'' ([[Bloomberg L.P.]]).[http://allafrica.com/stories/200810271813.html Ghana: Cfao Almost Quadruples Profit]. ''allafrica.com'' ([[AllAfrica.com]]). It was formed in 1909 and is currently headed by Thomas Pelletier. ==Overview== '''CFAO Ghana''' is a subsidiary of [[CFAO]] [[Automotive]], the largest automobile network in [[Africa]] and the [[Overseas departments and territories of France|overseas French territories]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mitsubishi-motors.com.gh/|title=Our Networks|publisher=Mitsubishi Motors|accessdate=3 December 2014}} It is also the exclusive Ghanaian distributor for seven internationally renowned brands which are [[Citröen]], [[Mitsubishi Motors]], [[Mitsubishi Fuso Truck and Bus Corporation|Fuso]], [[DAF Trucks]], [[Bridgestone]], [[SYM Motors|SYM]] and [[Suzuki]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cfao-automotive.com/en/subsidiaries/cfao-motors-ghana/|title=Trusted network of choice for leading global brands|publisher=CFAO Motors Ghana|accessdate=3 December 2014}} ==Operations== CFAO Motors Ghana covers the whole Ghana from its three branches in [[Takoradi]], [[Accra]] and [[Kumasi]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cfao-automotive.com/en/subsidiaries/cfao-motors-ghana/|title=Efficiency boosted by a strong local presence|publisher=CFAO Motors Ghana|accessdate=3 December 2014}} The company comprises over 129 personnel work together in meeting the needs of customers including after - sales service. CFAO works with clients by distributing consumer goods and other equipment. It also deals with motor vehicles.[http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/economy/stock_quote.php?Quote=CFAO&view=information Company Information - CFAO Ghana]. ghanaweb.com. The company is authorized to set up, undertake and operate commercial, technical and industrial [[Business|enterprises]], and any other activities connected therewith. The Company operates in three segments which are Motor, [[Technologies]] and Europcar. '''Motor division''' is engaged in the sales and services of vehicles and equipment. '''Technologies division''' sells and services office equipment and machines. '''Europcar division''' is engaged in car rentals and other related activities.{{cite web|url=http://www.securities.com/Public/company-profile/GH/CFAO_Ghana_Limited_en_2035684.html|title=Company Description|publisher=EMIS|accessdate=3 December 2014}} ==Executives== The following is a list of directors of CFAO Ghana: * Alhaji Asumah Banda * E.K. Akyea-Djamson * Herve Bijonneau * Jacques Zymelman {{cite web|url=http://www.securities.com/Public/company-profile/GH/CFAO_Ghana_Limited_en_2035684.html|title=Key Executives|publisher=EMIS|accessdate=3 December 2014}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.cfaomotors-ghana.com/?id_rub1=32&id_rub2=80&id_rub3=119&col=32&col2=80 CFAO Ghana official homepage] *[http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/economy/stock_quote.php?Quote=CFAO&page=1 GhanaWeb.com] *[http://www.alacrastore.com/company-snapshot/CFAO_Ghana_Ltd-1098079 CFAO Ghana at Alacrastore] {{Automotive industry in Ghana}} {{Economy of Ghana}} {{-}} [[Category:Automotive companies of Ghana]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies of Ghana]] [[Category:Vehicle manufacturing companies established in 1909]] {{ghana-stub}} {{Africa-company-stub}}

{{Infobox book | name = Daskal Philip Psalter | author = Daskal Philip | language = Bulgarian | country = | genre = | published = | publisher = | isbn = | exclude_cover = | italic title = <!--(see above)--> | image = Daskal Philip.PNG | image_size = | alt = | caption = | audio_read_by = | title_orig = | orig_lang_code = | title_working = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | series = | release_number = | subject = | set_in = | publisher2 = | pub_date = 1692 | english_pub_date = | media_type = ink and illumination on parchment | pages = | awards = | isbn_note = | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | native_wikisource = | wikisource = | notes = | website = }} The '''Daskal Philip Psalter''' is a 17th-century [[Bulgaria]]n [[illuminated manuscript|illuminated]] [[psalter]]. It was produced in 1692.
==Analysis== The psalter, is written in [[History of Bulgarian|Middle Bulgarian]] [[Cyrillic]] and contains the text of the [[Psalms]] copied by the Bulgarian daskal Philip. Of particular importance is the miniature of King David. The pages have dimensions 20.5 х 14 centimeters.
The manuscript is part of the collection of the Library of the [[University of Sofia]] "St. Clement of Ohrida" in [[Sofia]].
==See also== * [[Sofia Psalter]], c. 1337 * [[Tomić Psalter]], c. 1360 * [[Gospels of Tsar Ivan Alexander]], 1355–1356
==References== *[https://www.europeana.eu/portal/record/2063614/BU_280_06.html Psalter, Daskal Philip], europeana *[http://sudigital.org/?q=node/2722 Псалтир на даскал Филип], Psalter of Daskal Philip
==External links==

revision.text:
{{Infobox Union |name= GFWTUB |country= [[Bahrain]] |affiliation= none |members= |full_name= General Federation of Workers Trade Unions in Bahrain |native_name= |image= |founded= 2002 |current= |head= |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= |merged_into= |office= |people= |website= |footnotes= }} <!-- Include all unused fields for future use. See [[template talk:Infobox Union]] for usage. -->
The '''General Federation of Workers Trade Unions in Bahrain''' (GFWTUB) is a national [[trade union]] federation in [[Bahrain]]. It was established in 2002 when the King created the [[Workers Trade Union Law]] granting workers the right to organize collectively.<ref>{{cite book | year = 2005 | title = Trade Unions of the World | editor = [[International Centre for Trade Union Rights|ICTUR]] et al., | edition = 6th | publisher = John Harper Publishing | location = London, UK | isbn = 0-9543811-5-7 }}</ref>
The [[International Confederation of Free Trade Unions]]' Annual Survey 2005 highlighted: "Bahrain, a bright spot in an otherwise dismal landscape of persistent labour rights violations in the Middle East".<ref>{{cite web | title=Bahrain, a bright spot... | work=ICFTU Online | url=http://www.icftu.org/displaydocument.asp?Index=991222886&Language=EN | accessdate=2006-10-17 }}</ref> According to the ICFTU:
:''Bahrain has set the standard for the Gulf region in terms of positive developments. The right to form trade unions has existed since 2002, although only one national trade union centre is recognised, and other rights are still limited. The General Federation of Bahrain Trade Unions held its founding congress in January 2004 and in December became the first organisation in the Gulf States to become a member of the ICFTU. It has been actively involved in tripartite discussions, including on labour legislation.''<ref>{{cite web | title=Bahrain: Annual Survey of Violations of Trade Union Rights (2005) | work=ICFTU Online | url=http://www.icftu.org/displaydocument.asp?Index=991222248&Language=EN | accessdate=2006-10-17 }}</ref>
In October 2006, [[Hamad bin Isa Al Khalifa|King Hamad]] signed a law banning the sacking of employees engaged in trade union activities. Under an amended law, the courts must reinstate a sacked worker and award them compensation if it is proved that they were sanctioned for such activities.<ref>{{cite web | title=Sackings banned | work=Gulf Daily News | url=http://www.gulf-daily-news.com/Story.asp?Article=159050&Sn=BNEW&IssueID=29211 | accessdate=2006-10-16 }}</ref>
The King's move follows criticism by the ICTFU of the sacking in July 2005 of [[Gulf Air]]'s trade union head shortly after his election.
The establishment of the Federation was part of a number of key labour reforms introduced under the Minister of Labour, [[Majeed Al Alawi]].
==References==
{{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *[http://www.gulf-daily-news.com/Story.asp?Article=158515&Sn=BNEW&IssueID=29206 ILO experts to launch labour market project ] Gulf Daily News, 12 October 2006 *[http://www.gulf-daily-news.com/Story.asp?Article=158522&Sn=BNEW&IssueID=29206 Project to lay ground for labour reforms], Gulf Daily News, 12 October 2006 *[http://www.icftu.org/displaydocument.asp?Index=991223920&Language=EN Bahrain: Annual Survey of Violations of Trade Union Rights (2006)] ICTFU, 6 January 2006 *[http://www.icftu.org/displaydocument.asp?Index=991219171&Language=EN Bahrain trade union movement shows the way for region], ICTFU, 8 April 2004
{{Portal|Organized labour}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} The '''Heroic Age of Antarctic Exploration''' was an era which began at the end of the 19th century, and ended after the [[First World War]]; the [[Shackleton–Rowett Expedition]] of 1921–22 is often cited by historians as the dividing line between the "Heroic" and "Mechanical" ages.Smith, p. 414The historian [[Aant Elzinga]] gives the much later date of 1945, considering [[World War II]] to be the turning point in Antarctic research.{{cite book|first= Aang|last= Elzinga|title= Changing Trends in Antarctic Research|publisher= Springer|year= 1993|location= Dordrecth|isbn= 978-0-58-528849-9}} During the Heroic Age the [[Antarctic]] continent became the focus of international efforts that resulted in intensive scientific and geographical exploration, in which 17 major [[List of Antarctic expeditions|Antarctic expeditions]] were launched from ten countries.Barczewski, pp. 19–20. The common factor in these expeditions was the limited nature of the resources available to them before advances in [[Transport in Antarctica|transport]] and [[Telecommunications in Antarctica|communication technologies]] revolutionized the work of exploration.Huntford, p. 691 – "before machines took over." This meant that each expedition became a feat of endurance that tested, and sometimes exceeded its personnel's physical and mental limits. The "heroic" label, bestowed later, recognized the adversities which had to be overcome by these pioneers, some of whom did not survive the experience; during this period 19 expedition members died. During the course of these expeditions the [[Geographical pole|geographical]] and [[South Magnetic Pole|magnetic poles]] were both reached. The achievement of being first to the geographical [[South Pole]] was a primary object in some expeditions, and was the sole rationale for [[Roald Amundsen]]'s venture. However, this was not the only aspect of polar exploration during this time; other expeditions worked with defined objectives in different areas of the continent. As a result of all this activity, much of the continent's coastline was discovered and mapped, and significant areas of its interior were explored. The expeditions also generated large quantities of scientific data and specimens across a wide range of scientific disciplines, the examination and analysis of which would keep the world's scientific communities busy for decades.For example, the scientific results of the [[Scottish National Antarctic Expedition]], 1902–04 were still being published in 1920 (Speak, p. 100). 25 volumes of results from the [[Terra Nova Expedition]], 1910–13 had been published by 1925. ({{cite web|title= British Antarctic Expedition 1910–13|url= http://www.oxforddnb.com/public/themes/95/95247.html|publisher= Oxford Dictionary of National Biography|accessdate=4 December 2008}}) ==Origins== {{Infobox fictional location | name = Terra Australis | colour = #C0C0C0 | image = Typus Orbis Terrarum drawn by Abraham Ortelius.jpg | imagesize = 250px | caption = "Terra Australis Nondum Cognita" is the large continent on the bottom of this 1570 map by [[Abraham Ortelius]] | source = | creator = | genre = | type = Hypothetical continent | locations = | people = }} The exploration of the South Pole has been an off and on area of focus; this particular period, the Heroic Age of Antarctic Exploration, is not the first intensive period of Antarctic exploration. Curtailing what is commonly known as the [[Age of Exploration]], British explorer [[James Cook]] would be one of the few explorers who would travel to that Southern region of the world. The discoveries of [[Second voyage of James Cook|his second voyage]] (1772–1775) would change the global map forever.{{cite book|first= I.|last= Kaye|title= Captain James Cook and the Royal Society |publisher= Notes and Records of the Royal Society of London, Vol. 24, No.1|year= 1969|location= London}} Prior to his expedition it was believed that a large continent known as ''[[Terra Australis]]'' occupied the majority of the Southern hemisphere. However, Cook discovered that no such land mass existed though massive ice floes prevented his reaching Antarctica proper. He did hypothesize that, based upon the amount of ice, there must be an originating land mass. Subsequently, exploration of the Southern regions of the world came to a great halt. However, a period of interest arose again between 1819 and 1843.{{cite book|last= American Association for the Advancement of Science |title= The Exploration of the Antarctic Regions|publisher= Science, Vol. 9, No. 223|year= 1887|location= New York}} As Europe settled after a period of revolution, war, and unrest, explorers [[Fabian Gottlieb von Bellingshausen|Bellingshausen]], [[John Biscoe|Biscoe]], [[John Balleny|Balleny]], [[Charles Wilkes]], [[Jules Dumont d'Urville|Dumont D'Urville]], and [[James Clark Ross]] sought greater knowledge of the Antarctic regions. The primary goal of these explorers was to penetrate the ice walls that hid Antarctica proper, beginning with Bellingshausen's circumnavigation of the region, D'Urville's discovery of the first rocky land formation, and culminating in Wilkes's discovery of Victoria Land, featuring the volcanoes now known as Mt. Terror and Mt. Erebus. These explorers, despite their impressive contributions to South Polar exploration, were unable to penetrate the interior of the continent and, rather, formed a broken line of discovered lands along the coastline of Antarctica. {{Infobox settlement | name = Antarctic Region, 1848 | native_name = | other_name = | settlement_type = | image_skyline = | image_caption = | image_flag = | image_shield = | motto = | nickname = | etymology = | subdivision_type = Country | subdivision_name = | subdivision_type1 = | subdivision_name1 = | subdivision_type2 = | subdivision_name2 = | subdivision_type3 = | subdivision_name3 = | subdivision_type4 = | subdivision_name4 = | image_map = Known_Antarctic_Region_1848.jpg | map_caption = The known Antarctic region after the 1819–1843 period of intensive exploration. | pushpin_map = | pushpin_relief = | pushpin_map_caption = | coordinates = | coordinates_footnotes = | established_title = | established_date = | area_footnotes = | area_total_km2 = | area_total_sq_mi = | area_land_sq_mi = | area_water_sq_mi = | elevation_footnotes = | elevation_m = | elevation_ft = | population_as_of = | population_footnotes = | population_total = | population_density_km2 = auto | population_density_sq_mi= | population_demonym = | timezone1 = | utc_offset1 = | timezone1_DST = | utc_offset1_DST = | postal_code_type = | postal_code = | area_code_type = | area_code = | geocode = | iso_code = | website = | footnotes = }} What followed this period of Antarctic interest is what historian [[Hugh Robert Mill|H. R. Mill]] called 'the age of averted interest'.{{cite book|first= G.E.|last= Fogg|title= The Royal Society and the Antarctic|publisher= Notes and Records of the Royal Society London, Vol. 54, No. 1|year= 2000|location= London, The Royal Society}} Following the expedition South by the ships [[HMS Erebus (1826)|HMS ''Erebus'']] and [[HMS Terror (1813)|HMS ''Terror'']] under James Clark Ross (January, 1841), he suggested that there were no scientific discoveries, or 'problems', worth exploration in the far South. It is considered that Ross' influence, as well as the loss of the [[Franklin expedition]] in the Arctic, led to disinterest in polar inquiry, particularly by The Royal Society: the British-founded organization that helped oversee many Arctic explorations, including those that would be made by Shackleton and Scott. However, in the following twenty years after Ross' return, there is a general lull internationally in Antarctic exploration. [[File:SirJMurrayatwork.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Sir John Murray|alt=An old bearded man drawing or measuring with a compass.]] The initial impetus for the Heroic Age of Antarctic Exploration is somewhat contested as it is a vague international movement. George von Neumayer of Hamburg, also an Antarctic explorer, worked to renew Antarctic exploration in 1861 onwards as he worked in an observatory in Melbourne. His particular interests were the importance of meteorology and how more information of the South Pole could lead to more accurate weather predictions. This helps explain German involvement in Antarctic research. Another, particularly British, impetus more closely tied to the period is a lecture given by [[John Murray (oceanographer)|Dr. John Murray]] entitled "The Renewal of Antarctic Exploration", given to the Royal Geographical Society in London, November 27, 1893.{{cite book|first= John|last= Murray|title= The Renewal of Antarctic Exploration|publisher= The Geographical Journal, Vol. 3, No. 1|year= 1894|location= London}} Murray advocated that research into the Antarctic should be organised to "resolve the outstanding geographical questions still posed in the south".Crane, p. 75 Furthermore, the Royal Geographic Society instated an Antarctic Committee shortly prior to this, in 1887, which successfully incited many whalers to explore the Southern regions of the world and foregrounded the lecture given by Murray. In August 1895 the Sixth International Geographical Congress in London passed a general resolution calling on scientific societies throughout the world to promote the cause of Antarctic exploration "in whatever ways seem to them most effective".{{cite book|author = Borchgrevink, Carstens|title= ''First on the Antarctic Continent|url= https://books.google.com/?id=aMRgMxzhEI8C&pg=PA24&lpg=PA24&dq=Southern+Cross+Expedition|publisher = George Newnes Ltd|year= 1901|accessdate=11 August 2008|isbn = 978-0-90-583841-0}} pp. 9–10 Such work would "bring additions to almost every branch of science". The Congress had been addressed by the Norwegian [[Carsten Borchgrevink]], who had just returned from a whaling expedition during which he had become one of the first to set foot on the Antarctic mainland. During his address, Borchgrevink outlined plans for a full-scale pioneering Antarctic expedition, to be based at [[Cape Adare]].{{cite book|author = Borchgrevink, Carstens|title= ''First on the Antarctic Continent|url= https://books.google.com/?id=aMRgMxzhEI8C&pg=PA24&lpg=PA24&dq=Southern+Cross+Expedition|publisher = George Newnes Ltd|year= 1901|accessdate=11 August 2008|isbn = 978-0-90-583841-0}} pp. 4–5 However, the Heroic Age was inaugurated by an expedition launched by the Belgian Geographical Society in 1897; Borchgrevink followed a year later with a privately sponsored expedition.Jones, p. 59Some histories consider the ''Discovery'' expedition, which departed in 1901, as the first proper expedition of the Heroic Age. See {{cite web|title= Mountaineering and Polar Collection – Antarctica|url= http://www.nls.uk/collections/foreign/mountains/antarctica-2.html|publisher= National Library of Scotland|accessdate= 19 November 2008|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090623023005/http://www.nls.uk/collections/foreign/mountains/antarctica-2.html|archivedate= 23 June 2009|df= dmy-all}} The designation "heroic age" came later; the term is not used in any of the early expedition accounts or memoirs, nor in the biographies of polar figures which appeared in the 1920s and 1930s. It is not clear when the term was first coined or adopted generally; it was used in March 1956 by the British explorer [[Duncan Carse]], writing in ''[[The Times]]''. Describing the first crossing of [[South Georgia Island|South Georgia]] in 1916, he wrote of "three men from the heroic age of Antarctic exploration, with 50 feet of rope between them, and a carpenter's adze".Carse, quoted by M. and J. Fisher, p. 389 ==Expeditions, 1897–1922== '''Notes''' # The summaries in the table do not include the scientific work carried out by these expeditions, each of which brought back findings and specimens across a wide range of disciplines. # The table does not include the numerous whaling voyages that took place during this period, or sub-Antarctic expeditions such as that of [[Carl Chun]] in 1898–99, which did not penetrate the [[Antarctic circle]].{{cite web|title= Carl Chun Collection|url= http://www.archiveshub.ac.uk/news/03061104.html|publisher= Archive Hub|accessdate= 11 December 2008|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://archive.is/20120527065840/http://www.archiveshub.ac.uk/news/03061104.html|archivedate= 27 May 2012|df= dmy-all}} The abortive Cope Expedition of 1920–22, which collapsed through lack of funding, is likewise excluded, though two men were landed from a Norwegian whaler and spent a year on the Antarctic peninsula.{{cite web|title= John Lachlan Cope's Expedition to Graham Land 1920–22|url= http://www.spri.cam.ac.uk/resources/expeditions/blax/|publisher= Scott Polar Research Institute|accessdate=11 December 2008}} # † denotes leader died during expedition {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! scope="col" |Dates ! scope="col" |Country ! scope="col" |Expedition {{nowrap|name(s)}} ! scope="col" |Ship(s) ! scope="col" |Leader ! scope="col" class="unsortable"|Expedition summary ! scope="col" class="unsortable"|Refs |- | scope="row" | {{nowrap|1897–99 }} | {{BEL}} | [[Belgian Antarctic Expedition|{{nowrap|Belgian Antarctic}} Expedition]] | ''[[RV Belgica (1884)|Belgica]]'' | [[File:Adrien de Gerlache.jpg|80x80px|alt=A bearded man of about 30 years in fur hat and winter coat.]]
{{sortname|Adrien de|Gerlache}} | This was the first expedition to [[overwinter]] within the [[Antarctic Circle]], after the ship was icebound in the [[Bellingshausen Sea]]. It collected the first annual cycle of Antarctic observations. It also reached 71°30'S, and discovered the [[Gerlache Strait]]. First Mate [[Roald Amundsen]] would later lead the first arrival at the [[South Pole]], in 1911. | {{cite web|title= Antarctic Explorers – Adrien de Gerlache|url= http://www.south-pole.com/p0000083.htm|publisher= South-pole.com|accessdate=22 September 2008}}Huntford (''Last Place on Earth'') pp. 64–75 |- | scope="row" | 1898–1900 | {{flag|United Kingdom|name= UK}} | British Antarctic Expedition 1898
([[Southern Cross Expedition]]) | [[SS Southern Cross (1886)|''Southern Cross'']] | [[File:Borchgrevink.jpg|100x100px|alt=A man with moustache in a winter coat with a hat covering his ears.]]
{{sortname|Carsten|Borchgrevink}} | The first expedition to overwinter on the Antarctic mainland ([[Cape Adare]]), it was the first to make use of dogs and sledges. It made the first ascent of The [[Ross Ice Shelf|Great Ice Barrier]],The Great Ice Barrier later became formally known as the [[Ross Ice Shelf]]. The older name has been used in this table, in keeping with the nomenclature of the Heroic Age. and set a [[Farthest South]] record at 78°30'S. It also calculated the location of the [[South Magnetic Pole]]. | {{cite web|title= The Forgotten Expedition|url= http://www.heritage-antarctica.org/english/forgotten%2Dexpedition/|publisher= Antarctic Heritage Trust|accessdate= 13 August 2008|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091120185702/http://www.heritage-antarctica.org/english/forgotten-expedition/|archivedate= 20 November 2009|df= dmy-all}}{{cite web|title= Borchgrevink, Carsten Egeberg (1864–1934)|url= http://www.adb.online.anu.edu.au/biogs/A070353b.htm|publisher = Australian Dictionary of Biography Online Edition|accessdate=10 August 2008}}Preston, p. 14 |- | scope="row" | 1901–04 | {{flag|United Kingdom|name= UK}} | National Antarctic Expedition 1901
([[Discovery Expedition]]) | ''[[RRS Discovery|Discovery]]''
''Morning'' (relief ship)
''[[Terra Nova (ship)|Terra Nova]]'' (relief ship) | [[File:Scott of the Antarctic crop.jpg|90x90px|alt=A man in ceremonial military uniform.]]
{{sortname|Robert Falcon|Scott}} | It made the first ascent of the Western Mountains in [[Victoria Land]], and discovered the polar plateau. Its southern journey set a new Farthest South record, 82°17'S.Modern recalculations based on analysis of photographs taken at the farthest south location suggest that the actual latitude may have been 82°11. See Crane, pp. 214–15 Many other geographical features were discovered, mapped and named. This was the first of several expeditions based in [[McMurdo Sound]]. | Preston, pp. 57–79Crane, p. 253 (map); pp. 294–95 (maps)Fiennes, p. 89 |- | scope="row" | 1901–03 | {{flagicon|German Empire}}[[Germany]] | First German Antarctic Expedition
([[Gauss Expedition]]) | [[Gauss (ship)|''Gauss'']] | [[File:Erich dagobert von drygalski.jpg|100x100px|alt=A man with moustache in a smart dress.]]
{{sortname|Erich von|Drygalski}} | The first expedition to investigate eastern Antarctica, it discovered the coast of [[Kaiser Wilhelm II Land]], and [[Gaussberg|Mount Gauss]]. The expedition's [[Gauss (ship)|ship]] became trapped in ice, which prevented more extensive exploration. | {{cite web|title= Erich von Drygalski 1865–1949|url= http://www.south-pole.com/p0000085.htm|publisher = South-pole.com|accessdate=23 September 2008}}Mill, pp. 420–24Crane, p. 307 |- | scope="row" | 1901–03 | {{SWE}} | [[Swedish Antarctic Expedition]] | ''[[Antarctic (ship)|Antarctic]]'' | [[File:Ottonord.jpg|100x100px|alt=A middle-aged bearded man in a smart dress.]]
{{sortname|Otto|Nordenskiöld}} | This expedition worked in the east coastal area of [[Graham Land]], and was marooned on [[Snow Hill Island]] and [[Paulet Island]] in the [[Weddell Sea]], after the sinking of its expedition ship. It was rescued by the Argentinian naval vessel ''Uruguay''. | {{cite web|last= Goodlad|first= James A.|title= Scotland and the Antarctic, Section II: Antarctic Exploration|url= http://gdl.cdlr.strath.ac.uk/scotia/gooant/gooant020303.htm|publisher= Royal Scottish Geographical Society|accessdate=23 September 2008}}{{cite web|title= Otto Nordenskiöld 1869–1928|url= http://www.south-pole.com/p0000091.htm|publisher= South-pole.com|accessdate=23 September 2008}}Barczewski, p. 90 |- | scope="row" | 1902–04 | {{flag|United Kingdom|name= UK}} | [[Scottish National Antarctic Expedition]] | ''Scotia'' | [[File:WilliamBruce.jpg|100x100px|alt=A middle-aged bearded man wearing a tie, waistcoat and jacket.]]
{{sortname|William Speirs|Bruce}} | The permanent [[Orcadas Base|Orcadas weather station]] in [[South Orkney Islands]] was established. The [[Weddell Sea]] was penetrated to 74°01'S, and the coastline of [[Coats Land]] was discovered, defining the sea's eastern limits. | {{cite web|title= Scotland and the Antarctic, Section 5: The Voyage of the ''Scotia''|url= http://gdl.cdlr.strath.ac.uk/scotia/gooant/gooant05.htm|publisher= Glasgow Digital Library|accessdate=23 September 2008}}Speak, pp. 82–95 |- | scope="row" | 1903–05 | {{FRA}} | [[French Antarctic Expedition|Third French Antarctic Expedition]] | ''Français'' | [[File:Jean-Baptiste Charcot.jpg|100x100px|alt=An older bearded man with a hat wearing a tie and coat. He is keeping a pile of papers or documents under his arm.]]
{{sortname|Jean-Baptiste|Charcot}} | Originally intended as a relief expedition for the stranded Nordenskiöld party, the main work of this expedition was the mapping and charting of islands and the western coasts of [[Graham Land]], on the [[Antarctic peninsula]]. A section of the coast was explored, and named [[Loubet Land]] after the President of France. | {{cite book|last= Mills|first= William James|title= Exploring Polar Frontiers|url= https://books.google.com/?id=PYdBH4dOOM4C&pg=PA135&lpg=PA135&dq=Jean-Baptiste+Charcot|publisher= ABC-CLIO|accessdate=23 September 2008|isbn= 978-1-57-607422-0|date= 11 December 2003}} pp. 135–139{{cite web|title= Jean-Baptiste Charcot|url= http://www.south-pole.com/p0000095.htm|publisher= South-pole.com|accessdate=24 September 2008}}(''Francais'' voyage)Mill, pp. 431–32 |- | scope="row" | 1907–09 | {{flag|United Kingdom|name= UK}} | British Antarctic Expedition 1907
([[Nimrod Expedition]]) | [[Nimrod (ship)|''Nimrod'']] | [[File:Shackletonhead.jpg|100x100px|alt=A young man wearing a tie, jacket and waistcoat.]]
{{sortname|Ernest|Shackleton}} | The first expedition led by Shackleton. Based in [[McMurdo Sound]], it pioneered the [[Beardmore Glacier]] route toward the [[South Pole]], and the (limited) use of motorised transport. Its southern march reached 88°23'S, a new Farthest South record 97 [[nautical miles|geographical miles]] from the Pole. The Northern Party reached the location of the [[South Magnetic Pole]]. | {{cite web|title= Scotland and the Antarctic, Section 3: Scott, Shackleton and Amundsen|url= http://gdl.cdlr.strath.ac.uk/scotia/gooant/gooant030202.htm|publisher= Glasgow Digital Library|accessdate=24 September 2008}}Riffenburgh, pp. 309–12 (summary of achievements)Huntford (''Shackleton'' biography) p. 242 (map) |- | scope="row" | 1908–10 | {{FRA}} | [[French Antarctic Expedition|Fourth French Antarctic Expedition]] | [[Pourquoi Pas ? IV|''Pourquoi-Pas? IV'']] | [[File:Jean-Baptiste Charcot.jpg|100x100px|alt=An older bearded man with a hat wearing a tie and coat. He is keeping a pile of papers or documents under his arm.]]
{{sortname|Jean-Baptiste|Charcot}} | This continued the work of the earlier French expedition with a general exploration of the Bellingshausen Sea, and the discovery of islands and other features, including [[Marguerite Bay]], [[Charcot Island]], [[Renaud Island]], [[Mikkelsen Bay]], [[Rothschild Island]]. | {{cite web|title= Jean-Baptiste Charcot|url= http://www.south-pole.com/p0000096.htm|publisher= South-pole.com|accessdate=24 September 2008}}(''Pourquoispas?'' voyage) |- | scope="row" | 1910–12 | {{JPN}} | [[Japanese Antarctic Expedition]] | ''Kainan Maru'' | [[File:Group shirase.jpg|alt=An Asian man in military uniform with a hat.]]
{{sortname|Nobu|Shirase}} | The first non-European Antarctic expedition carried out a coastal exploration of [[King Edward VII Land]], and investigated the eastern sector of the Great Ice Barrier, reaching 80°5'S. | {{cite book|authorlink= Roald Amundsen|last= Amundsen|first= Roald|title= The South Pole, Vol II|publisher= C Hurst & Co|year= 1976|location= London|isbn=09-0398-347-8}}{{cite web|title= Nobu Shirase, 1861–1946|url= http://www.south-pole.com/p0000105.htm|publisher= South-pole.com|accessdate=24 September 2008}} |- | scope="row" | 1910–12 | {{NOR}} | [[Amundsen's South Pole expedition]] | ''[[Fram]]'' | [[File:Nlc amundsen.jpg|120x120px|alt=A bearded man wearing a bow tie and coat.]]
{{sortname|Roald|Amundsen}} | First to the South Pole: Amundsen set up camp on the Great Ice Barrier, at the [[Bay of Whales]]. He discovered a new route to the polar plateau via the [[Axel Heiberg Glacier]]. A party of five led by Amundsen reached the [[South Pole]] via this route on 14 December 1911. | Amundsen, Vol I pp. 184–95; Vol II, pp. 120–134Huntford (''Last Place on Earth''), pp. 446–74{{cite web|title= Roald Amundsen|url= http://www.norway.org.uk/history/expolorers/amundsen/amundsen.htm|publisher= Norwegian Embassy (UK)|accessdate=25 September 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080422100914/http://www.norway.org.uk/history/expolorers/amundsen/amundsen.htm |archivedate = 22 April 2008}} |- | scope="row" | 1910–13 | {{flag|United Kingdom|name= UK}} | British Antarctic Expedition 1910
([[Terra Nova Expedition]]) | ''[[Terra Nova (ship)|Terra Nova]]'' | [[File:Scottski.jpg|110x110px|alt=Man in winter coat wearing a balaclava or ski mask style headgear.]]
{{sortname|Robert Falcon|Scott}}† | Scott's last expedition, based like his first in [[McMurdo Sound]]. Scott and four companions reached the South Pole via the Beardmore route on 17 January 1912, 33 days after Amundsen. All five died on the return journey from the Pole, through a combination of starvation and cold. | Scott's Last Expedition Vol I pp. 543–46, pp. 580–95Preston, pp. 184–205{{cite web|title= Explorer and leader: Captain Scott|url= http://www.nmm.ac.uk/Scott|publisher= National Maritime Museum|accessdate= 27 September 2008|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081202113611/http://www.nmm.ac.uk/scott|archivedate= 2 December 2008|df= dmy-all}} |- | scope="row" | 1911–13 | {{flagicon|German Empire}}[[Germany]] | [[Second German Antarctic Expedition]] | ''Deutschland'' | [[File:Wilhelm Filchner.jpg|100x100px|alt=Middle-aged man wearing a tie, waistcoat and jacket.]]
{{sortname|Wilhelm|Filchner}} | The objective was the first crossing of Antarctica. The expedition made the southernmost Weddell Sea penetration to date, reaching 77°45'S, and discovering [[Luitpold Coast]], [[Filchner-Ronne Ice Shelf]], and [[Vahsel Bay]]. It failed to establish a shore base from which to mount its transcontinental march, and after a long drift in the Weddell Sea pack ice it returned to [[South Georgia Island|South Georgia]]. | Huntford (''Shackleton'' biography), pp. 366–68{{cite web|title= Wilhem Filchner, 1877–1957|url= http://www.south-pole.com/p0000103.htm|publisher= South-pole.com|accessdate=28 September 2008}} |- | scope="row" | 1911–14 | {{AUS}} and {{NZL}} | [[Australasian Antarctic Expedition]] | [[SY Aurora|''Aurora'']] | [[File:Mawson1914.jpg|100x100px|alt=Man wearing a tie, waistcoat and jacket.]]
{{sortname|Douglas|Mawson}} | The expedition concentrated on the stretch of Antarctic coastline between Cape Adare and Mount Gauss, carrying out mapping and survey work on coastal and inland territories. Discoveries included [[Commonwealth Bay]], [[Ninnis Glacier]], [[Mertz Glacier]], and [[Queen Mary Land]]. | Mills, p. 129 et seq.{{cite web|title= Mawson, Sir Douglas 1882–1958|url= http://www.adb.online.anu.edu.au/biogs/A100444b.htm|publisher= Australian Dictionary of Biography|accessdate=28 September 2008}} |- | scope="row" | 1914–17 | {{flag|United Kingdom|name= UK}} | [[Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition]] | [[Endurance (1912 ship)|''Endurance'']]
| [[File:Shackletonold.jpg|100x100px|alt=Bearded middle-aged man with a cowboy hat.]]
{{sortname|Ernest|Shackleton}} | Another transcontinental crossing attempt. It failed to land the Weddell Sea shore party after ''Endurance'' was trapped and crushed in ice. The expedition then rescued itself after a series of exploits, including a prolonged drift on an [[drift ice|ice-floe]], [[Voyage of the James Caird|Shackleton's open boat journey]], and the first crossing of [[South Georgia Island|South Georgia]]. | Shackleton, pp. 63–85Alexander, pp. 143–53 |- | scope="row" | 1914–17 | {{flag|United Kingdom|name= UK}} | [[Ross Sea party]] In support of
Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition | ''Aurora'' | [[File:Mack crop 3.jpg|100x100px|alt=A man in formal dress. Crop from a group picture.]]
{{sortname|Aeneas|Mackintosh}}† | Its objective was to lay [[depot]]s across the Great Ice Barrier, to supply the party crossing from the Weddell Sea. All the required depots were laid, but in the process three men, including the leader Mackintosh, lost their lives. | Tyler-Lewis, pp. 193–197 |- | scope="row" | 1921–22 | {{flag|United Kingdom|name= UK}} | [[Shackleton–Rowett Expedition]] | ''[[Quest (ship)|Quest]]'' | [[File:Shack-endurance.jpg|100x100px|alt=Man wearing a thick jumper and over it suspenders.]]
{{sortname|Ernest|Shackleton}}† | Vaguely defined objectives included coastal mapping, a possible continental circumnavigation, the investigation of sub-Antarctic islands, and oceanographic work. After Shackleton's death on 5 January 1922, ''Quest'' completed a shortened programme before returning home. | Huntford (''Shackleton''), p. 684Fisher, p. 483 |} ==Expedition deaths during the Heroic Age== Nineteen men died on Antarctic expeditions during the Heroic Age. Of these, four died of illnesses unrelated to their Antarctic experiences, and two died from accidents in New Zealand. |url=http://www.coolantarctica.com/Antarctica%20fact%20file/History/antarctic_whos_who_belgica.htm |title=Adrien de Gerlache, Belgica Belgian Antarctic Expedition 1897 – 1899 |publisher=Cool October 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} * Harlof Klovstad, medical officer on the [[Southern Cross Expedition]], 1898–1900, died of unrecorded causes during 1900.{{cite web|title= Norway's Forgotten Explorer|url= http://www.heritage-antarctica.org/english/ExpeditionMembersContinued/|publisher= Antarctic Heritage Trust|accessdate=10 August 2008}} * Jorgen Petersen, First Mate on the ''[[Southern Cross]]'', died in 1900 while returning in the ship from [[Australia]]. * Bertram Armytage, a member of the [[Nimrod Expedition]], 1907–09, died of self-inflicted gunshot wounds, 12 March 1910.Riffenburgh, p. 304 * [[Hjalmar Johansen]], a member of Amundsen's 1910–12 expedition, died of self-inflicted gunshot wounds, 9 January 1913.Huntford (''Last Place on Earth''), p. 529 ==End of the Heroic Age== There are different views about when the Heroic Age of Antarctic Exploration came to an end. Shackleton's ''Endurance'' expedition is sometimes referred to as the last Antarctic expedition of the Heroic Age.Alexander, pp. 4–5{{cite web|title= Scotland and the Antarctic, Part 3|url= http://gdl.cdlr.strath.ac.uk/scotia/gooant/gooant03.htm|publisher= Glasgow Digital Library|accessdate=4 December 2008}} Other chroniclers extend the era to the date of Shackleton's death, 5 January 1922, treating the [[Shackleton–Rowett Expedition|Shackleton–Rowett]], or ''Quest'' expedition, during which Shackleton died, as the final chapter of the Age.{{cite web|title=Antarctic History – The Heroic Age of Antarctic Exploration|url=http://www.coolantarctica.com/Antarctica%20fact%20file/History/The_heroic_age_of_Antarctic_exploration.htm|publisher=Cool Antarctica|accessdate=9 November 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67Z0HPi6X?url=http://www.coolantarctica.com/Antarctica%20fact%20file/History/The_heroic_age_of_Antarctic_exploration.htm|archivedate=10 May 2012|df=dmy-all}} According to Margery and James Fisher, Shackleton's biographers: "If it were possible to draw a distinct dividing line between what has been called the Heroic Age of Antarctic Exploration and the Mechanical Age, the Shackleton–Rowett expedition might make as good a point as any at which to draw such a line".Fisher, p. 449 A journalist inspecting the ship before she sailed reported "Gadgets! Gadgets! Gadgets everywhere!". These included wireless, an electrically heated crow's nest and an "odograph" that could trace and record the ship's route and speed. {{quote | The heroic era of Antarctic exploration was ‘heroic’ because it was anachronistic before it began, its goal was as abstract as a pole, its central figures were romantic, manly and flawed, its drama was moral (for it mattered not only what was done but how it was done), and its ideal was national honour. It was an early testing-ground for the racial virtues of new nations such as Norway and Australia, and it was the site of Europe’s last gasp before it tore itself apart in the Great War. | Tom Griffiths, ''Slicing the Silence: Voyaging to Antarctica'' }} ==See also== {{portal|Antarctica}} * [[Arctic exploration]] * [[Farthest South]] * [[History of Antarctica]] * [[List of Antarctic {{Infobox radio station | name = KZKZ | image = | city = [[Manila]], [[The Philippines]] | branding = KZKZ | slogan = | airdate = June 1922 | last airdate = 1924 | frequency = 729 kHz AM | format = [[Dark (broadcasting)|Silent]] | power = five-watt transmitter (1922-1924), 100-watt transmitter (1924) | erp = | class = | callsign_meaning = | owner = Henry Hermann (1922-1924)
[[Radio Corporation of the Philippines]] | website = }} '''KZKZ''' (729 kHz [[AM broadcasting|AM]]) was the second [[radio station]] in the [[Philippines]]. It began broadcasting in 1922 and was founded by Henry Hermann, the owner of the Electrical Supply Company in [[Manila]]. The station was upgraded in 1924 to a 100-watt station and its call letters KZKZ were adopted. Later that year, the station was sold to the [[Radio Corporation of the Philippines]].[http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=613920&publicationSubCategoryId=51 Juan De La Cruz tunes in - The Freeman (retrieved on September 21, 2010)] The first radio broadcast in the Philippines was made in 1922 from Nichols air field by using a five-watt transmitter. In 1926, the organization began work on constructing two of the largest radio stations in Asia with the idea of maintaining direct Manila-San Francisco service.[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,880868,00.html Time Magazine, September 20, 1926] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.oldradio.com/archives/international/philippines.html Philippine Broadcast History] ==See also== *[[DYRC]] *[[DZLT-AM|DZLT]] {{Defunct Metro Manila Radio}} {{coord missing|Philippines}} [[Category:Defunct radio stations in Metro Manila]] [[Category:Radio stations established in 1922]] [[Category:Radio stations disestablished in 1924]] [[Category:1922 establishments in the Philippines]] [[Category:1924 disestablishments in the Philippines]] {{Philippines-radio-station-stub}} {{Asia-hist-stub}}

[[File:Romanian Patriarchal Cathedral, The Patriarchal Palace. Bucharest, Roamnia, Southeastern Europe.jpg|thumb|[[Dealul Mitropoliei|Romanian Patriarchal Cathedral in Bucharest]] is also the seat of Metropolis of Muntenia and Dobrudja]] The '''Metropolis of Wallachia and Dobrudja''', headquartered in [[Bucharest]], [[Romania]], is a [[Metropolis (religious jurisdiction)|metropolis]] of the [[Romanian Orthodox Church]].
==History== The Metropolis of Ungro-Wallachia was created, in 1359, by [[Patriarch Callistus I of Constantinople|Callistus I]], the [[Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople]] as the most senior church office of the Patriarchate of Constantinople, covering the territory of [[Wallachia]].
In 1872, the Metropolis of Ungro-Wallachia united with the [[Metropolis of Moldavia and Bukovina|Metropolis of Moldavia]] to form the [[Romanian Orthodox Church]]. The Metropolis of Ungro-Wallachia, who received the title of Primate Metropolitan in 1865, became the head of the General Synod of the Romanian Orthodox Church. In 1990, it became Metropolis of Muntenia and Dobrudja.

{{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Portugal}} "Neste barco à vela" | image = | caption = | year = 1987 | country = Portugal | artist = Jorge Mendes,
Alfredo Azinheira | as = [[Nevada (Portuguese band)|Nevada]] | with = | language = Portuguese | languages = | composer = Alfredo Azinheira,
Jorge Mendes | lyricist = Alfredo Azinheira | conductor = Jaime Oliveira | place = 18th | points = 15 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1987pt from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev = Não sejas mau para mim | prev_link = Não sejas mau para mim | next = Voltarei | next_link = Voltarei }} '''"Neste barco à vela"''' ("In this sailing boat") was the [[Portugal|Portuguese]] entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1987]], performed in [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] by [[Nevada (Portuguese band)|Nevada]]. The song is in praise of Portugal itself. The two singers describe their "overfull boat" which apparently has a "childish look" as travelling on a "path of hope". The song was performed eighth on the night, following [[Italy]]'s [[Umberto Tozzi]] and [[Raffaele Riefoli|Raf]] with "[[Gente di mare]]" and preceding [[Spain]]'s [[Patricia Kraus]] with "[[No estás solo]]". At the close of voting, it had received 15 points, placing 18th in a field of 22. It was succeeded as [[Portugal in the Eurovision Song Contest|Portuguese representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1988|1988 Contest]] by [[Dora (singer)|Dora]] with "[[Voltarei]]". {{Eurovision Song Contest 1987}} {{Portugal in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Neste barco a vela}} [[Category:Eurovision songs of Portugal]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of 1987]] [[Category:Portuguese-language songs]] [[Category:1987 songs]] {{portugal-stub}}

Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.5)
revision.text:
In [[international finance]], the '''redundancy problem''', also known as the '''n − 1 problem''', is a problem of inequality of the number of policy instruments and the number of targets at the international level,<ref>{{citation |author1=Ronald Winthrop Jones |author2=Peter B. Kenen | publisher = Elsevier | title = Handbook of International Economics, Volume 2 | year = 1984 | page = 1186 }}</ref> suggested by [[Robert Mundell]] in {{harvtxt|Robert Mundell|1969}}.<ref name = "Gandolfo 1995" /><ref>{{citation |author = [[Ronald McKinnon]] |page = 2 |volume = Working Paper No. 419 |location = |publisher = Stanford Center for International Development |title = Rehabilitating the Unloved Dollar Standard |url = https://siepr.stanford.edu/?q=system/files/shared/pubs/419_McKinnon.pdf |year = 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150527235627/https://siepr.stanford.edu/?q=system%2Ffiles%2Fshared%2Fpubs%2F419_McKinnon.pdf |archivedate = 2015-05-27 |df = }}</ref>
This problem does not occur at the one-country level.<ref name = "Gandolfo 1995">{{citation | author = Giancarlo Gandolfo | page = 227 | location = | publisher = Springer Science & Business Media | title = International Economics Two. | year = 1995}}.</ref>
Suppose the number of countries in the world is ''n''. Because this world is closed, one country's [[balance of payments]] surplus must be equal to another's deficit, and vice versa. Thus the sum of all countries' net payments positions must be zero. Therefore, if ''n'' − 1 countries out of ''n'' countries have determined their balances of payments, that of the ''n''th country is determined automatically.<ref name = "Alan 2002">{{citation | author = Alan Professor Winters | page = 397 | location = | publisher = Routledge | title = International Economics | year = 2002}}.</ref> This fact implies that, if all of the ''n'' countries have payments objectives, only ''n'' − 1 countries can achieve the payments objectives. In other words, all of the payments objectives can not be achieved simultaneously.
Similarly, if there are ''n'' [[currency|currencies]] in the world, only ''n'' − 1 [[exchange rate]]s can be "independent" because the exchange rate is a price of one money relative to another.<ref name = "Alan 2002" /> Other rates which are not independent are calculated as [[cross rate]].
There are only ''n'' − 1 countries to be determined, which implies the ''n'' th country is required to refrain from intervening its exchange rate. [[Benign neglect]] is one example for this fact.<ref>{{cite book|author=Ronald Winthrop Jones, Peter B. Kenen|title=Handbook of International Economics, Volume 2|url={{Google books|jpEV2Q13hA8C|Handbook of International Economics, Volume 2|page=PA1186|plainurl=yes}}|page=1186}}</ref><ref>{{citation |editor1=Maria Cristina Marcuzzo |editor2=Lawrence H. Officer |editor3=Annalisa Rosselli | page = 38 | volume = | location = | publisher = Routledge | title = Monetary Standards and Exchange Rates | year = 2002 }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} *{{Cite journal|author=Robert Mundell|date=1969|title=The Redundancy problem and the World price level |journal = Monetary problems of International Economy|pages=379–382|publisher=Chicago university|editor=Robert Mundell and Alexender. K, and Swoboda.|ref=harv}}

Najświętszego Serca Pana Jezusa
(''Cathedral of the Sacred Heart of Jesus'') |cocathedral = |area_km2 = 6,000 |population = 601,598 |population_as_of = 2010 |catholics = 591,608 |catholics_percent= 98.3 |pope = {{Incumbent pope}} |bishop = [[Jan Franciszek Wątroba]] |metro_archbishop = [[Adam Szal]] |coadjutor = |auxiliary_bishops= Edward Eugeniusz Białogłowski |emeritus_bishops = Kazimierz Górny |website = [http://www.diecezja.rzeszow.pl/ Website of the Diocese] }} The '''Roman Catholic Diocese of Rzeszów''' ({{lang-la|Rzeszovien(sis)}}) is an [[diocese]] located in the city of [[Rzeszów]] in the [[Ecclesiastical province]] of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Przemyśl|Przemyśl]] in [[Poland]]. ==History== * March 25, 1992: Established as Diocese of Rzeszów from the Diocese of Przemyśl and [[Diocese of Tarnów]] ==Leadership== * [[Bishop]]s of Rzeszów (Roman rite) ** Bishop [[Kazimierz Górny]] (March 25, 1992 – June 14, 2013) ** Bishop [[Jan Wątroba]] (since July 19, 2013) [[Image:Biskup Jan Watroba 2013.jpg|thumb|220px|left| Bishop Jan Wątroba]] ==See also== *[[Roman Catholicism in Poland]] ==Sources== * [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/rzes0.htm GCatholic.org] * [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/drzes.html Catholic Hierarchy] * [http://www.rzeszow.opoka.org.pl/ Diocese website] * [http://www.wsd.rzeszow.pl/?q=node/5 Major Seminary of Rzeszów] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{coord|50.013057|22.019616|format=dms|display=title|type:landmark}} {{Roman Catholic dioceses in Poland}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rzeszow}} [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses in Poland]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in 1992]] [[Category:Rzeszów]] [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses and prelatures established in the 20th century]] {{Poland-stub}} {{Europe-RC-diocese-stub}}

{{unreferenced|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox radio station | name = Shalkar radio | image = | city = [[Astana]], [[Almaty]] | area = [[Kazakhstan]] | branding = | slogan = | airdate = January 1, 1966 | frequency = | format = new/[[Talk radio|talk]] | erp = | class = | owner = [["Kazakhstan" corporation|Kazakhstan Radio and Television Corporation]] | sister_stations = | website = [http://shalkarfm.kz Shalkar radio] | callsign_meaning = | former_callsigns = }} '''Radio «Shalkar»''' - a structural unit of Kazakh Radio, which broadcasts only in the state language. Start broadcasting on January 1, 1966. On October 1, 2012 translated into a new broadcasting media center «QazMedia Ortalygy» in Astana. Included in the [[Kazakhstan Radio and Television Corporation|RTRC JSC «Kazakhstan»]].
==History== Radio «Shalkar» - a structural unit of Kazakh Radio, which broadcasts only in the state language. History of specialized radio has more than 40 years. To date, the time is broadcasting 18 hours a day.
The basic concept of the radio «Shalkar» - the preservation and development of the spiritual heritage of the Kazakh people.
Thematic focus: informational, analytical, literary, musical, historical and educational programs.
Since April 2009, the radio «Shalkar» comes out in a new format. Programs have become more dynamic and focused primarily on the younger generation of listeners.
==Local programming== *«Алғыр қазақ» *«Көзайым» *«Дәстүр» *«Елім менің» *«Қазақтың 1000 күйі» *«Терме» *«Төртінші билік» *«Жақсының жары» *«Қазақтың қол өнері» *«Кеш жарық, балақай» *«Әуелетіп ән салса» *«Денсаулық» *«Жұлдызды түн» *«Тал бесіктен жер бесікке дейін» *«Аққулы айдын» *«Жусан исі» *«Кешеден келдік бүгінге» *«Тіл-майдан» *«Заңгер кеңесі» *«Сазды сәлем» *«Наркескен» *«Жайдарман» *«Әлқисса» *«Қайырлы таң, қазақ елі!» *«Дидар-ғайып» *«Қазақ бол!» *«Біздін елдің жігіттері» *«Бақ қараған» *«Ардагерлер» *«Өнер өлкесі» *«Ата-жұрт» *«Атадан калған асыл сөз» *«Ғасыр ғибраттары»
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://shalkarfm.kz/ Shalkar radio] *[http://kaztrk.kz RTRC JSC «Kazakhstan»]

revision.text:
[[File:Flickr - tpower1978 - Japan Open (1).jpg|thumb|Shizuka Arakawa during the Japan Gymnasics Open]]
[[Association Football]] (also known as Soccer) is the most popular sport in almost all [[Asia]]n countries. [[Cricket]] is the second most popular sport in Asia.<ref>[[Asian nations at the FIFA World Cup]]</ref> Other popular '''sports in Asia''' include [[baseball]], [[basketball]], [[badminton]] and [[table tennis]] among others.
==Association football== [[File:Azadistadium.jpg|thumb|Azadi Stadium in Iran]]
The [[Asian Football Confederation]] was founded in 1954. They organize several tournaments for national teams, most notably the [[AFC Asian Cup]] since 1956 and [[AFC Women's Asian Cup]] since 1975, as well as qualifying tournaments for the [[FIFA World Cup]], [[FIFA Women's World Cup]] and the Summer Olympics. The [[AFC Champions League]] is Asia's premier tournament for clubs, first held in 1967.
The AFC members are split into five regional federations: [[West Asian Football Federation|West]], [[Central Asian Football Association|Central]], [[South Asian Football Federation|South]], [[East Asian Football Federation|East]] and [[ASEAN Football Federation|South East]]. These federations organize regional football championships.
The most successful Asian countries in international men's competitions have been Japan and South Korea in East, and Saudi Arabia and Iran in the West. In women's football, East Asian have been dominant, especially Japan, China and North Korea. Asia has been more successful in women's football than in men's football.
The [[2002 FIFA World Cup]] was hosted jointly by Japan and South Korea. It was the first edition not held in Europe or the Americas. The [[2022 FIFA World Cup]] is scheduled to take place in Qatar, but it was announced that it could be cancelled for bribery during the bidding process.
The People's Republic of China hosted the first edition of the FIFA Women's World Cup in [[1991 FIFA Women's World Cup|1991]], as well as the [[2007 FIFA Women's World Cup|2007]] edition.
{{Asia topic|Football in}}
==Bandy== [[File:Збірна України з хокею з м’ячем IMG 1619.jpg|thumb|right|[[China national bandy team]] with [[Ukraine national bandy team|Ukraine]]]] [[Bandy]] is a growing sport in Asia. While traditional in some former Soviet republics, especially [[Kazakhstan national bandy team|Kazakhstan]] (bandy is the only team sport in which Kazakhstan has captured World Championship medals), it is more or less new in some other ones. President [[Tsakhiagiin Elbegdorj]] invited [[Mongolia national bandy team|the Mongolian national team]] after its bronze medal in Division B of the [[2017 Bandy World Championship|2017 World Championship]].<ref>[http://theubpost.mn/2017/02/07/president-praises-national-bandy-team/ President praises national bandy team]</ref> [[Japan national bandy team|Japan]] also reached the semi-final. Consequently, Mongolia beat them in the bronze match. [[China national bandy team|China]] started to compete in the World Championship in [[2015 Bandy World Championship|2015]] and [[China women's national bandy team|the women's national team]] in [[2016 Women's Bandy World Championship|2016]]. Both Division B of [[2018 Bandy World Championship|the men's tournament 2018]] and [[Women's Bandy World Championship#Top results year by year|2018 Women's World Championship]] (in which Japan plan to debut) will be played in China, which will be the first time either tournament is held in a totally Asian country (the area north and west of the [[Ural River]] is located in Europe, thus Kazakhstan, where the [[2012 Bandy World Championship|2012 World Championship]] was held, is a [[List of transcontinental countries|transcontinental country]]). In September 2017 it was announced that an [[Federation of International Bandy|FIB]] office for development and marketing in Asia would open in [[Harbin]].<ref>https://translate.google.se/translate?hl=sv&sl=ru&u=http://www.rusbandy.ru/news/11081</ref> Apart from the countries mentioned, Afghanistan, Armenia, India and Kyrgyzstan are also FIB members.<ref>[http://www.worldbandy.com/members.html FEDERATION of INTERNATIONAL BANDY - Members]</ref> In the Philippines an attempt started in 2016 to introduce [[rink bandy]].<ref>[http://sports.inquirer.net/211420/norweigan-aims-to-popularize-winter-sport-in-manila Norwegian aims to popularize winter sport in Manila]</ref> FIB is especially interested in having South Korea join the bandy community. As of 2017 negotiations are ongoing.<ref>https://translate.google.co.uk/translate?hl=en&sl=ru&u=http://www.rusbandy.ru/news/11237/</ref>
==Baseball== {{see also|Baseball in Japan}} [[File:The team at bat (in MAZDA Zoom-Zoom Stadium).JPG|thumb|Nippon Professional Baseball match in Hiroshima]]
Baseball is most popular sport in Japan, where it was introduced in the 1870s and became professional in the 1920s. The [[Japanese Baseball League]] was operated from 1936 to 1949, and reorganized into the [[Nippon Professional Baseball]] in 1950. Teams have been historically identified with their corporate owners, not where the team is based, and have often relocated to other cities.
Over 50 Japanese-born players have played in [[Major League Baseball]], including [[Ichiro Suzuki]], [[Hideki Matsui]], [[Koji Uehara]] and [[Hideo Nomo]].
The [[Japan national baseball team]] has won the 2006 and 2009 World Baseball Classic. [[High school baseball in Japan|High school baseball]] is also popular in Japan.
In South Korea, baseball was introduced in the 1900s and the [[KBO League]] was established in 1982. The Taiwan-based [[Chinese Professional Baseball League]] was established in 1989. Like the NPB, these two leagues feature teams owned by major corporations.
==Basketball==
[[Basketball]] is popular in a number of Asian countries. [[FIBA Asia]] is organized by [[International Basketball Federation]] (FIBA) and manages the sport over the region. Major contending nations are [[China]], [[Japan]], [[Philippines|the Philippines]], [[Iran]] and [[South Korea]].
The [[Philippines men's national basketball team|Philippines]] has the best finish in the [[FIBA World Cup]] from teams outside the Americas and Europe winning bronze in [[1954 FIBA World Championship]]. Also, the team took a fifth-place finish in 1936 Summer Olympics, the best finish by any team outside the Americas, Europe and Oceania. [[China men's national basketball team|China]] has dominated the [[FIBA Asia Championship]] since the 1970s while the Philippines, South Korea, Japan and Iran continues to be strong contenders. In women's basketball, the [[FIBA Asia Women's Championship]] has been fought between China, Japan and South Korea.
The [[FIBA World Cup]] was held in Asia in [[1978 FIBA World Championship|1978]] in the [[Philippines]] and [[2006 FIBA World Championship|2006]] in [[Japan]] and by 2019, China will host that year's edition. In [[2023 FIBA Basketball World Cup|2023]], the Philippines and Japan will once again host the World Cup, along with [[Indonesia]].
The main tournament for Asian basketball clubs is the [[FIBA Asia Champions Cup]], held since 1981.
==Boxing==
[[Boxing]] is a popular sport in [[Asia]] where there is a vast following of professional fights across the region. Its mostly popular in countries such as [[Japan]], [[Philippines|the Philippines]] and [[South Korea]]. The [[Philippines]] is the most dominant in terms of professional and amateur level with a history of world champions including eight division world champion [[Manny Pacquiao]].
==Cricket== [[File:Sachin Tendulkar drives a ball 2010.jpg|thumb|Indian batsman Sachin Tendulkar in a cricket test]]
[[Cricket]] is a popular sport in [[South Asia]]. Five countries have [[Test cricket|Test]] status: [[Afghanistan national cricket team|Afghanistan]], [[Bangladesh national cricket team|Bangladesh]], [[India national cricket team|India]], [[Pakistan national cricket team|Pakistan]], and [[Sri Lanka national cricket team|Sri Lanka]].
At the [[Cricket World Cup]], India has won two editions, while Pakistan and Sri Lanka have each won once. At the [[ICC World Twenty20]], three countries have won once. Bangladesh was known to be the weakest of the four teams (Afghanistan did not have test status before 2017), having won 7 out of 91 Test matches and 95 out of 309 [[One Day International]] matches.But now it making its mark in cricket after winning against the top quality sides in world cricket.
The [[Asian Cricket Council]] is a cricket organization which was established in 1983, to promote and develop the sport of cricket in Asia. Membership in the Asian Cricket Council is divided between five Test Status members, seven associate members and eleven affiliate members. Four Asian countries, namely Indonesia, Japan, Philippines and South Korea, are members of [[ICC East Asia-Pacific]] instead of the Asian Cricket Council, although Indonesia has applied for membership in the Asian Cricket Council.
The [[Asia Cup]] is the continental [[One Day International]] and [[Twenty20 International]] cricket tournament. The [[Indian Premier League]] a Twenty20 cricket tournament for franchise teams held since 2008.
The [[India–Pakistan cricket rivalry]] attracts up to one billion viewers. However, because of the tense [[India–Pakistan relations]], Test series have been interrupted between 1962 and 1977, 1999-2003 and since 2008.
==Cue Sports== [[Cue sports]] also known as Billiards Sports or Pool Sports are popular in Asia particularly in East and South Asian nations with Eight Balls, Nine Balls and Snooker being the most popular types. The [[Asian Confederation of Billiard Sports]] is the main governing body in Asia. Cue sports are played in [[Asian Games]] and other regional competitions. Various nations have produced world champions predominantly from the [[Philippines]], [[Taiwan]], [[Japan]] and [[Hong Kong]].<ref>http://www.acbs.qa/about/history/</ref>
The Philippines is often considered to be the pool capital of the world because many of the top players coming from the country. Filipino players are known for their exceptional mastery of the game and innovative strategies that have revolutionized the way the sport is played. This was known as the ''Filipino Invasion'' which was participated by various Filipino players including [[Billiard Congress of America Hall of Fame|Hall of Famers]] [[Efren Reyes|Efren ''The Magician'' Reyes]] and [[Francisco Bustamante]].<ref>https://www.academia.edu/12571559/The_Filipino_Invasion_of_Pool_Setting_New_Standards_in_the_Game</ref>
==Golf==
Few Asian male golf players have claimed wins in the [[PGA Tour]] or [[European Tour]]. The most successful ones have been [[K. J. Choi]], who has eight PGA Tour wins, a third place at the [[2004 Masters Tournament]] and three appearances at the [[Presidents Cup]], and [[Yang Yong-eun]], who won the [[2009 PGA Championship]].
In contrast, several Asian female golf players have claimed major tournament wins, most notable [[Inbee Park]] (seven), [[Se Ri Pak]] (five), [[Yani Tseng]] (five) and [[Jiyai Shin]] (two).
Notable men's golf tournaments in Asia are the [[WGC-HSBC Champions]] (China), [[CIMB Classic]] (Malaysia), the [[DP World Tour Championship, Dubai]] (United Arab Emirates). Meanwhile, the most notable women's golf tournaments in Asia are the [[LPGA KEB–Hana Bank Championship]] (South Korea), [[Blue Bay LPGA]] (China), [[Sime Darby LPGA Malaysia]] and [[Fubon LPGA Taiwan Championship]].
==Motorsport== [[File:Sato usgp 2004.jpg|thumb|Takuma Sato driving a BAR Honda]]
[[Motorsport]] is popular in Japan. The country has hosted several international races, such as the [[Japanese Grand Prix]] ([[Formula One]]), [[6 Hours of Fuji]] ([[FIA World Endurance Championship]]), [[Japanese motorcycle Grand Prix]] ([[Grand Prix motorcycle racing]]), [[Suzuka 8 Hours]] ([[FIM Endurance World Championship]]), [[Rally Japan]] ([[World Rally Championship]]), [[FIA WTCC Race of Japan]] ([[World Touring Car Championship]]), [[Indy Japan 300]] ([[IndyCar Series]]), [[NASCAR Thunder 100]] and [[Coca-Cola 500 (Motegi)|Coca-Cola 500]] ([[NASCAR Cup Series]]).
Japan has hosted professional championships like the [[Super GT]], [[Super Formula]], [[All Japan Sports Prototype Championship]], [[Japanese Touring Car Championship]], [[All Japan Road Race Championship]] and [[D1 Grand Prix]].
[[Kazuyoshi Hoshino]], [[Masahiro Hasemi]] and [[Toshio Suzuki (racing driver)|Toshio Suzuki]] won the 1992 [[24 Hours of Daytona]] with a [[NISMO]]; [[Masanori Sekiya]] won the [[1995 24 Hours of Le Mans]]; and [[Takuma Sato]] won the [[2017 Indianapolis 500]]. Other notable Japanese racecar drivers include [[Satoshi Motoyama]], [[Seiji Ara]], [[Satoru Nakajima]], [[Kazuki Nakajima]] and [[Kamui Kobayashi]].
The [[Macau Grand Prix]], held since 1954, is known for its [[Formula 3]], touring car and superbikes races.
[[Formula One]] started adding more races in Asia with the [[Malaysian Grand Prix]] in 1999, followed by the [[Bahrain Grand Prix]] and [[Chinese Grand Prix]] in 2004, [[Singapore Grand Prix]] in 2008, [[Abu Dhabi Grand Prix]] in 2009, [[Korean Grand Prix]] in 2010, [[Indian Grand Prix]] in 2013 and Azerbaijan's [[European Grand Prix]] in 2016.
Major circuits in China ([[Shanghai International Circuit|Shanghai]] and [[Zhuhai International Circuit|Zhuhai]]), [[Sepang International Circuit|Malaysia]], [[Sentul International Circuit|Indonesia]], [[Buriram United International Circuit|Thailand]], [[Bahrain International Circuit|Bahrain]], [[Dubai Autodrome|Dubai]] and [[Yas Marina Circuit|Abu Dhabi]] have hosted several other international championships like the FIA World Endurance Championship, World Touring Car Championship, FIM Road Racing Grand Prix Championship, [[Superbike World Championship]], [[GP2 Series]], [[GP2 Asia Series]], Super GT and [[V8 Supercars]].
In rallying, the [[Abu Dhabi Desert Challenge]] is held since 1991 and the [[Sealine Cross-Country Rally]] is held since 2012. Both are part of the [[FIA Cross Country Rally World Cup]] and [[FIM Cross-Country Rallies World Championship]]. Qatari driver [[Nasser Al-Attiyah]] has won 2011 and 2015 [[Dakar Rally]], the 2008 and 2015 [[FIA Cross Country Rally World Cup]], the [[Production World Rally Championship]] in 2006, and the 2014 and 2015 [[World Rally Championship-2]].
==Rugby league== {{Main|Rugby league in Asia}}
Rugby league in Asia is currently dominated by Lebanon. The [[Lebanon national rugby league team]] and [[Russia national rugby league team]] are so far the only Asian teams to have competed in the [[Rugby League World Cup]].
==Rugby union== {{Main|Rugby union in Asia}}
Rugby union in Asia is currently dominated by Japan. The [[Japan national rugby union team|Japanese national team]] are so far the only Asian team to have competed in the [[Rugby World Cup]], having appeared in all seven tournaments so far.
The [[Hong Kong Sevens]] is one of the most prestigious [[rugby sevens]] events in the world. it is held since [[1976]] and is part of the [[World Rugby Sevens Series]] since 2000. Other notable rugby sevens tournaments in Asia have been the [[Dubai Sevens]], [[Japan Sevens]], [[Singapore Sevens]], [[Malaysia Sevens]] and [[China Sevens]]. Japan is scheduled to host the [[2019 Rugby World Cup]].
The [[Top League]] is Japan's premier rugby club competition, founded in 2003. In 2016, the [[Sunwolves]] joined the Southern Hemisphere-based [[Super Rugby]]. The team is based in Tokyo but also plays home games in Singapore.
==Tennis==
The most successful Asian countries in tennis have been China, Japan and India.
In men's singles, [[Kei Nishikori]] was finalist at the 2014 US Open and two ATP Masters 1000 tournaments, whereas [[Vijay Amritraj]] reached quarter-finals at four Grand Slams and was semifinalist at the 1982 WCT Finals. In men's doubles, [[Leander Paes]] won eight Grand Slams tournaments and [[Mahesh Bhupathi]] won four Grand Slams tournaments.
In women's singles, [[Li Na]] won two Grand Slam titles at the 2011 French Open and 2014 Australian Open, whereas [[Kimiko Date-Krumm]] won four Japan Open titles was semifinalist at three Grand Slam tournaments. Notable women's doubles players include [[Sania Mirza]], [[Ai Sugiyama]], [[Hsieh Su-wei]], [[Peng Shuai]] and [[Zheng Jie]].
==Volleyball== [[File:China v Cuba volleyball (2796279799).jpg|thumb|China volleyball national team at the FIVB Volleyball World Grand Prix in Hong Kong]]
In men's volleyball, the [[Japan men's national volleyball team|Japan national team]] has won three Olympic gold medals, including a gold medal in 1972. Also, the team was third at the 1970 and 1974 World Championship, and second at the 1969 and 1977 World Cup. Japan has been less successful in the World League era. Meanwhile, [[South Korea men's national volleyball team|South Korea]] finished fourth at the 1978 World Championship and [[Iran men's national volleyball team|Iran]] finished sixth at the 2014 World Championship.
In women's volleyball, the [[China women's national volleyball team|China]] and [[Japan women's national volleyball team|Japan]] national teams are dominant. China has won three Olympic gold medals, two World Championships, four World Cups and a Grand Prix. Meanwhile, Japan has won two Olympic gold medals, three World Championships and a World Cup. [[South Korea women's national volleyball team|South Korea]] has also claimed third places at the Olympic Games, World Championship, World Cup and World Grand Prix.
==Games== [[File:Fireworks at the closing ceremonies of the 1988 Summer Games.JPEG|thumb|Closing ceremonies of the 1988 Summer Olympics at Seoul]]
Asia has hosted a total of five [[Olympic Games]]: three [[Summer Olympic Games]]: [[1964 Summer Olympics|1964]] in [[Tokyo]], [[1988 Summer Olympics|1988]] in [[Seoul]] and [[2008 Summer Olympics|2008]] in [[Beijing]], and two [[Winter Olympic Games]]: [[1972 Winter Olympics|1972]] in [[Sapporo]] and [[1998 Winter Olympics|1998]] in [[Nagano (city)|Nagano]]. The [[International Olympic Committee]] has selected 3 cities from Asia to host the next three Olympic Games: [[2018 Winter Olympics|2018]] in [[Pyeongchang]], [[2020 Summer Olympics|2020]] in Tokyo and [[2022 Winter Olympics|2022]] in Beijing. Beijing will be the first city to host both Summer and Winter Olympic Games.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/2022-winter-olympics_55bb4805e4b06363d5a1aa34 | title = IOC: Beijing To Host 2022 Winter Olympics | publisher = The Huffington Post |author= Stephen Wilson | accessdate = August 1, 2015}}</ref>
The three most successful countries at the Olympic Games are [[China at the Olympics|China]] (winners in 2008 and runners-up in 2004 and 2012), [[Japan at the Olympics|Japan]] (third in 1964 and 1968, fifth as recently as 2004) and [[South Korea at the Olympics|South Korea]] (fourth in 1988 and fifth in 2010 and 2012). Asian countries have dominated judo, taekwondo, badminton and table tennis, while they have also been successful in archery, diving, gymnastics and weightlifting.
The [[Far Eastern Championship Games]] was a [[multi-sport event]] held from 1913 to 1934, featuring competitors from all over Asia. After World War II, the [[Asian Games]], also called the Asiad, were established in 1951. The Asian Games are the world's second largest multi-sport event after the [[Olympic Games]].<ref>[http://www.sportsbizasia.com/news/events/asian-games-taps-threetime-olympic-sportscaster-sports-radio-talk-show/ Sportsbizasia.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101127010308/http://www.sportsbizasia.com/news/events/asian-games-taps-threetime-olympic-sportscaster-sports-radio-talk-show/ |date=2010-11-27 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.sports-city.org/news_details.php?news_id=8819&idCategory=56 Sports-city.org]</ref> There is also a [[Asian Winter Games|winter edition of Asian Games]], which was first held in [[1986 Asian Winter Games|1986]].
[[Israel]] has been banned from the Asian Games since 1978, with the AGF citing security reasons. However, Israeli sports officials contend that it was due to Arab and Chinese opposition to their participation. Samuel Lalkin, general security of the Israel Sports Federation, said "The excuse that we pose big security problems is completely ridiculous if you think that North Korea is competing. That's a worse problem, but they want to see us out. We can't take part because of what we are."<ref>https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=lR8MAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dl0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=2486,2066961&dq=israel+asian+games&hl=en</ref> Due to the [[Arab–Israeli conflict]], Israel sports federations have joined the European confederations.
Some Asian countries compete at the [[Commonwealth Games]], most notably India (4th in all-time medals), Malaysia (11th), Singapore (13th) and Pakistan (15th). The [[1998 Commonwealth Games|1998]] edition was held in [[Kuala Lumpur]], whereas the [[2010 Commonwealth Games|2010]] edition was held in [[Delhi]].
== Other == Other known sports include [[American football]], which is not played in Asia, but still broadcast on TV and radio. The most common program in American football is the [[Super Bowl]], a maelstrom event that is broadcast nearly worldwide. Various hangouts and bars with HDTVs show footage of the Super Bowl throughout Asia.
{{Asia topic|suffix=at the Olympics|article=no}} {{Asia topic|suffix=at the Asian Games|article=no}}
===Kabaddi=== [[Kabaddi]] is a contact sport originated in India. The game is popular in India, Pakistan and Bangladesh. It is gaining popularity in other countries like South Korea, Iran and Thailand. The national teams of these countries have competed in the [[Kabaddi World Cup (Standard style)|Kabaddi World Cup]]. [[Pro Kabaddi League]] of India is broadcast in many Asian countries.
==See also== *[[Asian Championship]] *[[Asia cup (disambiguation)|Asia cup]] *[[List of professional sports leagues in Asia]] *[[Australian rules football in Asia]] *[[Olympic Council of Asia]] *[[UCI Asia Tour]] *[[Sport in Africa]] *[[Sport in Europe]] *[[Sport in Oceania]] *[[Sport in South America]]
